raw_text:
Davenport hits out at Wimbledon
 
 World number one Lindsay Davenport has criticised Wimbledon over the issue of equal prize money for women.
 
 Reacting to a disputed comment by All England Club chairman Tim Phillips, the American said: "I think it is highly insulting if prize money is taken away. "Somebody, I think it was Mr Phillips, said they won't have money for flowers at Wimbledon. That's insulting." An All England club spokesperson denied Phillips made the remark, insisting: "He definitely didn't say it." The statement added: "It was said by someone else and was a humorous aside at the end of a radio interview when the conversation had moved to talking about the Wimbledon grounds."
 
 Davenport was speaking following the announcement that this week's Dubai Duty Free event will join the US and Australian Opens in offering equal prize money for women. "You hear about women playing only three sets while men play five," said Daveport. "And the best women are never going to beat the best men. "But it's a different game you go to watch with the women - it doesn't make it better or worse. "Hopefully we will be able to change people's minds."
 
 Serena Williams, who is also in Dubai, added: "I'm obviously for equal prize money. "Women's tennis is exciting. Men's tennis is exciting as well, but the women have it right now. "If you are bringing in the spectators you should be able to reap what everyone else is able to reap."
llama3.2:1b:
Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over equal prize money for women, saying it would be highly insulting and that some people said they wouldn't receive flowers at the tournament. An All England Club spokesperson denied this, claiming it was a humorous remark made by someone else. 

Davenport also expressed disagreement with the idea that women's tennis is inferior to men's, stating that their current situation allows them to compete equally and that spectators should be able to reap equal rewards.
llama3.2:3b: Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over equal prize money for women after a disputed comment by All England Club chairman Tim Phillips said they would no longer have flowers at Wimbledon if women's prize money were taken away. The club later denied the comment was made by Phillips, and instead attributed it to another person in a radio interview. Davenport stated that she hopes to change people's minds about equal prize money, and Serena Williams expressed support for equal pay saying "women's tennis is exciting".
gemma2:2b: Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over unequal prize money for women after All England Club chairman Tim Phillips made a controversial comment about removing funds for flowers on the grounds. Davenport, who spoke at the Dubai Duty Free event where equal prize money for women was announced, argued that men's tennis is often played in longer sets, highlighting gender disparity and the quality of women's play. Serena Williams supported Davenport's stance, emphasizing the excitement generated by women's tennis and advocating for equitable reward for players.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon over the issue of equal prize money for women, while All England Club chairman Tim Phillips denied any comment about women winning flowers. Davenport is supporting a decision by Dubai Duty Free events to offer equal prize money for women and Serena Williams agrees with her stance.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Lindsay Davenport criticizes Wimbledon over unequal prize money for women players, stating that she believes removing prize money would be insulting and that women's tennis games typically last only three sets while men's can go five. Davenport advocates for equal prize money at tournaments, saying the move could attract more spectators and change people's perceptions about which game is better or worse.
qwen2.5:3b: World number one Lindsay Davenport criticized Wimbledon for potential reduction of prize money for women after comments from All England Club chairman Tim Phillips about removing funds for flowers. Davenport stated it was insulting, though the club denied such remarks. She supported equal prize money for women following announcements at upcoming Dubai event. Davenport also mentioned women's tennis is equally exciting but currently receives less support financially compared to men's game. Serena Williams agreed with Davenport on equal prize money benefits for women's tennis.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Lindsay Davenport criticizing Wimbledon and some information from a nearby golf event.

First, I'll read through the text carefully. Davenport says she's upset with equal prize money for women in Wimbledon. She reacts to Tim Phillips' controversial comments. She thinks removing prize money would be insulting. She also mentions someone else saying he made a comment, but he didn't. 

Then, it talks about Dubai Duty Free event joining doubles events where both men and women get equal prize money. Serena Williams supports this, emphasizing that women's tennis is fun too, just like men's. She adds that if people bring in fans, they should be able to benefit as others can.

I need to make sure I include the key points: Davenport's criticism of Wimbledon, reaction from Phillips, mention Serena Williams' support and her reasons for supporting equal prize money.
</think>

Davenport criticized Wimbledon's equal prize money for women, reacting to Tim Phillips' controversial comments. She suggested removing prize money, stating it would be insulting. Some people, including a spokesperson, accused Phillips of making the comment, but he denied it. Davenport supported the Dubai Duty Free event in joining doubles events with equal prize money and praised Serena Williams for her support for women's tennis, emphasizing their excitement and the benefit for fans if they bring them.

She also pointed out how it's a different game for women watching matches with better men. Williams and Serena Williams agreed. Equal prize money is part of a wider movement towards gender equality in tennis, which they hope will one day be reflected on the court.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Lindsay Davenport, a top-ranked female tennis player, criticized Wimbledon for its disparity in prize money. She expressed disbelief and insult over an alleged comment by All England Club chairman Tim Phillips, suggesting that cutting prize money for women might lead to forgoing flower arrangements at the tournament. The club denied Phillips made such a remark, attributing it to a humorous aside in a radio interview about Wimbledon's grounds.

Davenport supported equal prize money for women's tennis events, citing the discrepancy in set counts and game excitement between men's and women's matches. She hoped that offering equal financial rewards would change spectators' perceptions about the value of women's tennis. Serena Williams, another prominent female player present at Dubai, echoed Davenport's stance, emphasizing that women's tennis is equally exciting and deserving of equivalent prize money to attract spectators.
